rubric.purpose: Evaluates how well content guides students through the learning process, including motivation, scaffolding, practice opportunities, and reinforcement strategies.

criteria.criterion: No connection to student prior knowledge

examples.example: Presenting advanced formulas without building intuition
Theory-only content with no application or practice
Learning objectives present but no motivational connection explaining why this matters to students

severity.label: Major

criteria.criterion: Poor balance between instruction and practice
BACKWARD DESIGN VIOLATIONS: Lesson teaches concepts not in homework/quiz (tangent)
BACKWARD DESIGN VIOLATIONS: Homework requires skills not taught in lessons (gap)

examples.example: One example for a complex multi-step process
No worked examples before practice problems
Lesson content tangential to homework - teaches material not assessed
Follow-up questions don't prepare for homework complexity

Issue: Question hint and explanation both refer to the "Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1," which students do not learn until the next lesson Impact: References concept students haven't learned yet; breaks scaffolding Fix: Rewrite Hint 1 and Explanation if appropriate

severity.backward_design_note: Content uses backward design: Exam → Quiz → Homework → Lessons. Lessons must directly prepare students for homework. Tangential content or insufficient preparation for homework are MAJOR violations.

examples.example: Some concepts over-explained while others under-explained
Jump in difficulty between practice problems
Inconsistent use of summaries and reviews
Could use more diverse example contexts
Slightly too much time on simple concepts

diagnostic_questions.question: Are complex concepts properly scaffolded with incremental steps?
Do students get adequate practice at each difficulty level?
Is there clear motivation for why students should learn this?
Are there enough worked examples before independent practice?
Does the content connect to what students already know?
Is feedback provided at appropriate intervals?
Are there opportunities for self-assessment?
BACKWARD DESIGN: Can students complete homework after this lesson?
BACKWARD DESIGN: Does every concept taught connect to an assessment?
BACKWARD DESIGN: Are there tangential topics not in homework/quiz?
BACKWARD DESIGN: Do follow-up questions build toward homework complexity?

good_practices.practice: Start with motivation and learning objectives
Build from concrete examples to abstract concepts
Provide worked examples before practice problems
Gradual release of responsibility (I do, we do, you do)
Regular check-in points and self-assessment opportunities

failure_modes.failure: No connection to student interests or goals
Assuming one example is sufficient for complex topics

cross_competency_interactions.interaction: Good structure enables effective pedagogical sequencing
Strong pedagogical flow maintains motivation and interest
Pedagogical progression should align with assessment difficulty
